definitions.definition: a thin string of cotton, wool, silk, etc. used for sewing or making cloth

examples.text: a robe embroidered with gold thread
the delicate threads of a spider’s web
You've pulled a thread in your jumper.

definitions.definition: an idea or a feature that is part of something greater; an idea that connects the different parts of something

examples.text: A **common thread** runs through these discussions.
The author skilfully draws together the different threads of the plot.
I **lost the thread** of the argument *(= I could no longer follow it)*.
The speaker **lost his thread** *(= forgot what he wanted to say)* halfway through the talk.
As the film progresses, the threads of the plot slowly begin to unravel.
I found it hard to follow the main thread of his argument.
On studying the different historians' accounts, common threads emerge.
Apart from one or two loose threads, the police now had the complete picture of what happened.

definitions.definition: a long, thin line of something

examples.text: A thread of light emerged from the keyhole.
Thin threads of blood glittered on his forehead and cheeks.

definitions.definition: a series of connected messages on email, social media, etc. that have been sent by different people
the raised line that runs around the length of a screw and that allows it to be fixed in place by twisting
to return to an earlier situation or way of life after a period doing something else

wordOrigin: Old English thrǣd (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch draad and German Draht, also to the verb throw. The verb dates from late Middle English.
